In such cases, the individual was able to select public land "in lieu" of the sold land, usually from public lands which would not normally be sold. Mullan & Hyde would obtain "in lieu" filings, copy the information and put a dummy name on the form, backdate the form, and then slip the fake form into the state and federal land office files. Purchasers of public land would then discover that even their "in lieu" land had been taken already. Mullan & Hyde became the state's leading firm in stealing "in lieu" land.
Mullan also personally profited from the sale of scrip land. Under the <a href="Morrill%20Land-Grant%20Acts">Morrill Act of 1862</a>, the federal government agreed to give each state of public land for each senator and representative. This land was to be used to support <a href="Land-grant%20university">state-run colleges and universities</a>. Ideally, the <a href="University%20of%20California">University of California</a> was to have retained this land as an investment, but the state provided so few funds to the university that it began selling Morrill Act land (known as "scrip land") at low prices. Colluding with public land officials, Mullan purchased large tracts of scip land before it became available to the public, then resold the land at inflated prices.
His unethical and illegal real estate dealings made Mullan a wealthy man, and he was able to retire the debts he had incurred from his stagecoach business. Mullan was fortunate: In February 1904, the federal government indicted Frederick A. Hyde for fraud and conspiracy. Hyde was accused of such widespread fraud that Congress appropriated $60,000 to bring 200 witnesses to Washington, D.C., to testify for the prosecution. The trial lasted four years, the longest trial in the District of Columbia to that time. Hyde was convicted on 42 counts of bribery, conspiracy, fraud, and other charges in June 1908, with the federal government recovering of land worth $1 million. Hyde was sentenced six months later to two years in federal prison and fined $10,000. He appealed his sentence to the Supreme Court, which declined to overturn it in 1912. Although Mullan escaped prosecution, his reputation was significantly tarnished for the rest of his life.
State agent in Washington, D.C..
In 1878, Mullan approached <a href="Governor%20of%20California">California Governor</a> <a href="William%20Irwin%20%28California%20politician%29">William Irwin</a>, offering to seek compensation from the federal government for a flaw in the <a href="California%20Statehood%20Act">California Statehood Act</a>. Traditionally, when admitting new states to the union, the federal government agreed to give the state 5 percent of the gross proceeds from the sale of federal land in that state. California's statehood act, enacted in 1850, neglected to include this provision. The state legislature passed a resolution in 1858 asking the federal government to pay, but no action on the resolution ever occurred. Mullan, who had spent a great deal of time in the past five years in the national capital working on his land business, now proposed to represent California in Washington, D.C., to secure these missing funds. In return, the state would pay Mullan 20 percent of the funds he collected. The state legislature passed a resolution authorizing the governor to appoint an agent, and Irwin appointed Mullan on November 1, 1878. The states of Nevada and Oregon, in similar straits as California, had by 1881 also hired Mullan as their agent to seek payment from the federal government. The Washington Territory did so as well in 1886.
Mullan did not just work on land claims. He acted as each state's agent on a wide variety of issues, including reimbursement for state expenditures during Indian wars, federal payments to volunteer soldiers during the Civil War, tax overpayments, and indemnities for state underpayments to the federal government. In time, he acted as a kind of lawyer-ambassador, drafting petitions to be presented to Congress and lobbying federal officials. Although Mullan won small settlements for his clients, giving him a solid income, Mullan lived far beyond his means—getting credit and spending money in anticipation of the major payday which awaited him if he could secure the California public lands payment.
California Governors <a href="George%20Clement%20Perkins">George Clement Perkins</a> and <a href="George%20Stoneman">George Stoneman</a> had both reappointed Mullan as the state's agent, and the state legislature had confirmed each appointment. In 1886, however, former California Surveyor General Robert Gardner initiated a campaign to discredit Mullan, accusing him of hiding the true size of the potential federal payment in order to enrich himself. In the spring of that year, former Governor Perkins sent a letter to Mullan, declaring he had made a mistake in appointing Mullan and allowing him so large a fee. Mullan's commission had not yet expired when Governor <a href="Washington%20Bartlett">Washington Bartlett</a> (Stoneman's successor) died in office on September 12, 1887. He was succeeded in office by <a href="Robert%20Waterman%20%28governor%29">Robert Waterman</a>, who threatened to revoke Mullan's commission in February 1888. Mullan wrote and published a book in defense of his work, but Republican-controlled news media and Gardner alleged that Mullan's commission had been improperly approved and that the state's congressional delegation could have done the same work at no cost. On January 18, 1889, Waterman revoked Mullan's commission. Mullan believed the Democratic-controlled legislature would reinstate him, and he moved to San Francisco temporarily to fight the charges against him. The state legislature established a commission to investigate the previous appointments, and the commission ruled in 1889 that governors Perkins and Stoneman had acted legally. Although Mullan remained dismissed, he believed he was still entitled to fees already won.
Mullan had obtained federal reimbursement of $228,000 in costs California incurred in raising volunteers during the Civil War. Mullan was due to receive $45,600, but the federal government's check arrived after the legislative commission's 1889 finding. The state declared that Mullan was not entitled to the fee, as payment was made after he had been dismissed. Mullan sued, and the case went to the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20California">Supreme Court of California</a>. The court held that the legislative commission had erred; a bill, not a resolution, was needed to effect Mullan's appointment as state agent. Mullan had no legally binding agreement with the state for any fees. Mullan reacted by asking the state legislature to pay him anyway. The state legislature passed a bill authorizing payment in 1897, but Governor <a href="James%20Budd">James Budd</a> vetoed it. The state legislature passed another bill in 1899, and Governor <a href="Henry%20Gage">Henry Gage</a> vetoed it.
California's actions emboldened Mullan's other clients as well. In 1894, Mullan won a $400,000 reimbursement for the state of Nevada and a $350,000 reimbursement for the state of Oregon. Both state legislatures swiftly passed laws requiring the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20the%20Treasury">United States Department of the Treasury</a> to issue checks directly to the state, bypassing Mullan and denying him any commission.
Bureau of Catholic Indian Missions.
In March 1869, newly inaugurated President <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a> announced the "Peace Policy", which radically changed the federal government's relationship with Native Americans. No longer would the United States seek to conquer tribes. The policy of signing treaties was abandoned; instead, reservations were established, and tribes were now seen as wards of the state, to be fed, housed, educated, and cared for. In the past, Indian agents were contractors who made a profit off their work with tribes, and corruption was rampant. Grant's new policy relied on Christian missionaries as agents, in the hope that priests and nuns would resist venality. In April 1869, Congress established the <a href="Board%20of%20Indian%20Commissioners">Board of Indian Commissioners</a> to oversee the establishment of government-approved Christian missions and reservation work. Due to extensive <a href="Anti-Catholicism">anti-Catholic</a> feeling in the United States, only <a href="Protestantism">Protestants</a> were appointed to the Board of Indian Commissioners, and Catholic missions were permitted at just seven of the 73 Indian agencies. In response, on January 2, 1874, the Catholic Church created the <a href="Bureau%20of%20Catholic%20Indian%20Missions">Catholic Commission for Indian Missions</a> to lobby the federal government for greater access to reservations. It was reorganized as the <a href="Bureau%20of%20Catholic%20Indian%20Missions">Bureau of Catholic Indian Missions</a> (BCIM) in 1879. Representatives of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Baltimore">Archbishop of Baltimore</a> and the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Philadelphia">Archbishop of Philadelphia</a> (and, later, the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20St.%20Louis">Archbishop of St. Louis</a>) led the BCIM, while a commissioner (a lay person) acted as the organization's lobbyist and fundraiser in Washington, D.C.
Retired Brigadier General <a href="Charles%20Ewing%20%28general%29">Charles Ewing</a>, foster brother and brother-in-law of <a href="General%20of%20the%20Army%20%28United%20States%29">General of the Army</a> <a href="William%20Tecumseh%20Sherman">William Tecumseh Sherman</a>, had served as Commissioner for Indian Missions since March 17, 1873. Ewing died suddenly of pneumonia on June 20, 1883. Father Jean Baptiste Brouillet, a long-time friend of Mullan's and the priest appointed by the Archbishop of Baltimore to lead the BCIM, sought to have Mullan named as the new commissioner. Mullan knew conditions in the west, he was a friend of many Native Americans, and he was a mover and shaker in the nation's capital. <a href="James%20Gibbons">James Gibbons</a>, Archbishop of Baltimore, approved the appointment in October 1883.
Mullan was a dedicated and effective commissioner. He attended nearly every meeting of the organization, spent months on the road each year visiting schools and reservation agencies, engaged in extensive fundraising, and published a book extolling the organization's accomplishments. By 1886, the number of Catholic schools had risen to 27 from 18, and Mullan had convinced the federal government to expand the annual student allotment to $149,000 from $39,000. While on the road, Mullan was also able to visit western Montana for the first time since completion of the Mullan Road. <a href="Henry%20Villard">Henry Villard</a>, president of the <a href="Northern%20Pacific%20Railway">Northern Pacific Railway</a>, invited Mullan and a wide range of prominent businessmen, political leaders, diplomats, bankers, and others to attend the driving of a gold spike at Montana's Clark Fork River near <a href="Gold%20Creek%20%28Montana%29">Gold Creek</a> (between <a href="Deer%20Lodge%2C%20Montana">Deer Lodge</a> and Missoula) on September 8, 1883, signifying completion of the Northern Pacific.
Mullan's role with the BCIM lasted only two and a half years. Father Brouillet died on February 5, 1884, from complications of severe <a href="hypothermia">hypothermia</a> and semi-paralysis after being caught in a blizzard in October 1882 at Devil's Lake Agency in the Dakota Territory. In May 1884, Archbishop Gibbons named Father Joseph Stephan to lead the BCIM. Mullan and Father Stephan never got along. In the fall of 1884, Father Stephan attempted to strip Mullan of his authority. Mullan protested to the archbishops, who reinstated his jurisdiction. Mullan and Stephan's relationship deteriorated. In September 1886, Mullan won passage of a resolution at a BCIM meeting ordering a financial investigation of the Catholic mission at the <a href="Rosebud%20Indian%20Reservation">Rosebud Indian Reservation</a>. The mission received no federal funds, and was outside the BCIM's jurisdiction. Moreover, Rosebud was overseen by <a href="Bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">Bishop</a> <a href="Martin%20Marty%20%28bishop%29">Martin Marty</a>, Stephan's mentor. Father Stephan subsequently accused Mullan of a number of unsubstantiated improprieties in a letter to Archbishop Gibbons. Gibbons stood by Stephan; Mullan had challenged a bishop's ethics and impugned the Catholic Church's reputation with private donors. Lay attorneys could be easily replaced, and Mullan was asked to resign. He refused. Mullan attended his last BCIM meeting in March 1887. When the organization met again in July, its bylaws had changed and Mullan's job no longer existed.
Later years and death.
Financial problems and illnesses.
Despite the loss of his job as California's agent, Mullan continued to live beyond his means into the 1890s. When his mother, Mary Bright Mullan, died in 1888, Mullan donated his portion of the estate to his two younger sisters, then living in Baltimore. He and his wife continued to live at 1310 Connecticut Avenue NW, a fashionable home a block south of <a href="Dupont%20Circle">Dupont Circle</a>, where they had two servants. Money woes were becoming apparent by 1891, when John unsuccessfully applied for back pay he believed was owed to him by the War Department. Even so, when John's brother Ferdinand died in 1892, he donated his portion of Ferdinand's estate to his sisters.
Mullan's wife, Rebecca, died in September 1898. John Mullan fell ill with an undetermined disease that same year. He became exceptionally weak, suffered from insomnia that could last for days, went long periods where he could not keep down solid food, and lost a significant amount of weight. He spent most of 1898 and 1899 under a nurse's care. No longer able to live alone, he moved in with his two daughters. He spent his time reading, and would occasionally travel to Baltimore or Annapolis to spend months living with his sisters. Mullan suffered a stroke in 1904 which left his left arm paralyzed and deprived his right arm of its fine motor control.
Unable to continue lobbying for the funds owed him, Mullan asked his daughter Emma to move to California in 1905 and continue this effort on his behalf. She did so, and that year won passage of a bill giving Mullan $45,000. Governor <a href="George%20Pardee">George Pardee</a>, under attack by Gardner and anti-corruption forces, decided to give Mullan only $25,000 (payable in two installments). Emma accepted the first payment of Pardee's grant, but pursued legal action to obtain the full $45,000 appropriated by the legislature. State courts ruled that the governor could not unilaterally amend legislation, and awarded Mullan the full $45,000 in 1910.
Despite his ill health, Mullan continued earn money doing limited legal work, primarily for miners and farmers suing the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20the%20Interior">United States Department of the Interior</a> and for the Catholic Church. But this generated too little income. His daughter, Mary, took a job as a <a href="stenography">stenographer</a> with the War Department, which brought in $900 a year. But this proved too little, given Mullan's heavy debts, and she resigned at the end of 1903. About 1905 or 1906, Emma and May Mullan founded a <a href="laundry">laundry</a> specializing in fine fabrics (such as lace), furs, and carpets. Known as the DeSales Hand Laundry, it was located at 1134 Connecticut Avenue NW.
John Mullan filed suit in <a href="United%20States%20Court%20of%20Claims">United States Court of Claims</a> on behalf of the state of Oregon, demanding that the federal government reimburse the state $690,000 for costs it incurred in raising volunteers during the Civil War. He won the case, but the state of Oregon refused to pay him. Emma Mullan then went to Oregon, where in 1907 the state legislature passed a bill awarding John Mullan $9,465. That same year, concerned for his children's future, Mullan made a new will in which he asked his sisters to give his share of his father's estate to the Mullan children.
Death.
Mullan's health deteriorated significantly in 1907. He was confined to a wheelchair, and later was confined to bed. With Emma having married and moved to California, May Mullan now took an apartment on 18th Street NW, where she and her father lived until the end of John Mullan's life.
Mullan's health began to decline rapid in December 1909. He died of unspecified causes at May Mullan's home in Washington, D.C., on December 28, 1909. His funeral was held at St. Mary's Church in Annapolis, and he was buried at St. Mary's Cemetery next to his parents and brothers. His brother, Dennis, and two sisters, Annie and Virginia, survived him as did his son, Frank, and daughters Emma and May.
At the time of his death, Mullan was penniless.
Personal life.
John Mullan's father, John Mullan Sr., died at his home in Annapolis on December 23, 1863, after a brief illness. His mother, Mary Bright Mullan, died on November 8, 1888.
John Mullan met his future wife, Rebecca Williamson, while stationed at Fort McHenry in Baltimore in 1856. They married on April 28, 1863. While the couple were living in San Francisco, they had five children. Rebecca and the children traveled to Europe in June 1885. John Mullan joined them there in late 1886, and the family did not return to the United States until 1887. Rebecca died at the Mullan home in Washington, D.C., on September 4, 1898, after a long and unspecified illness, and was buried in Bonnie Brae Cemetery in Baltimore.
The Mullans had five children, two of whom died in infancy just days after their birth. Their eldest surviving child, Emma Verita, was born in San Francisco in 1869. She married California state senator George Russell Lukens, and died childless in San Francisco on March 20, 1915. She was buried at <a href="Holy%20Cross%20Cemetery%20%28Colma%2C%20California%29">Holy Cross Catholic Cemetery</a> in <a href="Colma%2C%20California">Colma, California</a>. Their second eldest surviving child, Mary Rebecca (known as "May"), was born in San Francisco in 1871. She married D.C. banker Henry Hepburn Flather. They lived in the neighborhood of <a href="Georgetown%20%28Washington%2C%20D.C.%29">Georgetown</a> in Washington, D.C., and at their rural plantation home, <a href="Tulip%20Hill">Tulip Hill</a>, near <a href="Galesville%2C%20Maryland">Galesville, Maryland</a>. May Mullan died on December 31, 1962, at her home in Georgetown. She was buried at <a href="New%20Cathedral%20Cemetery">New Cathedral Cemetery</a> in Baltimore. At the end of her life, <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a> owned the house which abutted her back yard. The Mullan's youngest surviving child, Frank Drexel, was born in San Francisco in 1873 and married Mary Thomas Knapp. Frank died on February 18, 1936, of a heart attack, and was buried at Bonnie Brae Cemetery near to his mother.
John Mullan was a <a href="Racism">racist</a>. He was upset that the Civil War was being waged on behalf of African Americans and slavery rather than maintaining the union, yet also felt that secession was a "fraud" and that war would only lead to devastation. He believed that government was "a white man's government" and that laws should be written "by white men, for the benefit of white men." He believed "negro suffrage was forced upon the people", opposed Asian immigration (except for commercial purposes, such as <a href="coolie">coolie</a> labor), and opposed <a href="naturalization">naturalization</a> of Asian immigrants. "There is no way to whitewash Mullan's racism", historian Keith Petersen has written. "Even for his time and that place, his opinions were vile."
John Mullan III and Peter Mullan.
While Mullan was with Colonel Wright during the Coeur d'Alene War, he became the informal guardian of an orphan Yakima boy. On August 24, while encamped at Fort Taylor on the Snake River, three young Native American boys were captured by Wright's <a href="Picket%20%28military%29">pickets</a>. The three claimed to be brothers, and said they were Yakimas whose father had been killed by the Spokans five years earlier. Since then, they had been enslaved by the Spokans. Wright sent the two older boys to Fort Walla Walla. Mullan, however, persuaded Wright to let him take care of the youngest boy, who was about 14 years old. Wright agreed, and the boy accompanied Mullan for the rest of the military expedition. Mullan then left the boy, whom he named John in honor of an uncle, with his brother at Mullan's Walla Walla farm. This boy, who would have been John Mullan III, remained at the farm through 1864, until John Mullan Jr. lost the farm. The boy's whereabouts afterward are not known.
Oral tradition in the Spokane area may give an entirely different account of this child. This tradition holds that, in the fall of 1853, John Mullan met and married Mary Ann Finley (or "Finlay"), granddaughter of <a href="Jaco%20Finlay">Jaco Finlay</a>. Her age is unclear; she was born in either 1834 or 1836, making her either 19 or 17 years of age at the time of her marriage. She was one-half Native American. On June 9, 1855, Mary Ann died giving birth to a son, whom she named Peter Mullan. Historian Glen Adams argues that Peter Mullan was not John Mullan's child. Rather, a full-blood Native American probably impregnated Mary Ann, and that Peter is the boy whom John Mullan raised for a time. (Whether there was a John Mullan III in addition to Peter Mullan is not resolved by Adams.) Mullan biographers Louis C. Coleman and Leo Rieman examined much of the same evidence, and came to the same conclusions as Adams. Historian Keith Petersen, however, argues that it is plausible that Mullan fathered Peter Mullan. He argues that there is confusion over whether the mother was Mary Ann Finley or another woman, Rose Laurant. Laurant was Salish, and she may have lived with the Bitterroot Salish in 1853 when John Mullan was in the same area. Limited evidence in the oral tradition confuses Finley with Laurant, Petersen believes, and he concludes (a) that Peter Mullan is not the same person as John Mullan III, and (b) it is not unreasonable to believe that Peter Mullan was John Mullan's biological son.
In popular culture.
John Mullan is the namesake of the city of <a href="Mullan%2C%20Idaho">Mullan, Idaho</a>, which was founded in 1888.
In 1978, the Mullan Road was named a National Historic Engineering Landmark. Beginning in 1916, a series of marble monuments commemorating the Mullan Road were erected in Montana and Idaho. Each monument consists of an <a href="obelisk">obelisk</a> atop a square concrete base. On the front of the obelisk, in <a href="Relief%23High%20relief">high relief</a>, is an image of Mullan wearing his traditional <a href="moccasin">moccasin</a> boots and <a href="buckskins">buckskins</a>. He stands "<a href="contrapposto">contrapposto</a>", a <a href="pistol">pistol</a> tucked in his belt and his right hand holding <a href="flintlock">flintlock</a> <a href="rifle">rifle</a>. The monuments were designed by artist <a href="Edgar%20Samuel%20Paxson">Edgar Samuel Paxson</a>, a resident of Missoula, and were a project of the <a href="Society%20of%20Montana%20Pioneers">Society of Montana Pioneers</a> (a private organization of white men who settled in Montana prior to establishment of the Montana Territory). Seven statues were erected in Montana, and six in Idaho. Another 11 monuments, varying in shape and size from pyramidal cairns to slabs of granite, were erected in Washington state. These do not depict Mullan but mention his name.
The portion of <a href="Interstate%2090">Interstate 90</a> across Idaho is named the "Captain John Mullan Highway" in his honor.
There are several schools named in Mullan's honor, including Mullan Road Elementary School (Spokane, Washington), John Mullan Elementary School and Mullan Junior/Senior High School (Mullan, Idaho), and Mullan Trail Elementary School (<a href="Post%20Falls%2C%20Idaho">Post Falls, Idaho</a>).
Mullan Road is a neighborhood of the city of Missoula, Montana, named for Mullan.
Conferences and museums.
In 1989, a Mullan Day celebration was held in <a href="Mineral%20County%2C%20Montana">Mineral County, Montana</a>. By 2006, the event had evolved into a two-day conference about Mullan and the Mullan Road. The first conference was held in <a href="Helena%2C%20Montana">Helena, Montana</a>, and drew nearly 100 participants. The annual conference continued to be held, with the most recent being in 2016 in Helena.
The Mineral County Historical Museum in <a href="Superior%2C%20Montana">Superior, Montana</a>, publishes "Mullan Chronicles", a journal dedicated to research on John Mullan and the Mullan Road. The museum maintains a Mullan Room, dedicated to John Mullan and research about him.
